issues.title: To what extent should we describe NTRU
issues.author: sfluhrer
issues.body:
One issue is that, without NIST approval, there is not really definitive definition of NTRU.  The closest would be the NIST Round 3 submission, however the description there is targeted towards cryptographers/mathematicians, and I believe that a standard security engineer would not be able to understand it.  Should we try to write up an equivalent definition (targeted towards engineers without extensive math background)?
Should we include reference code (either in addition to or instead of the above description)?  Or, should we point people to the reference code in the Round 3 submission?

pulls.title: Sfluhrer ntru explination
pulls.author: sfluhrer
pulls.body: I added a lot of text; lets go with it...

comments.author: sfluhrer
comments.body:
> My comment was intended to be a request for changes. Explicitly adding now.

Hmmm, I have no idea what the 'mmark' format is supposed to be.  Do you have an example IETF draft in that format?

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body:
> Do you have an example IETF draft in that format?

You can take a look at the [post quantum signatures draft](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mesur-io/post-quantum-signatures/main/draft-ietf-cose-post-quantum-signatures.md) for an example.

The [mmark syntax documentation](https://mmark.miek.nl/post/syntax/#rfc-7991-xml-output), specifically the [RFC 7991 section](https://mmark.miek.nl/post/syntax/), will be helpful here.

reviews.author: brownoxford
reviews.body:
At some point along the way it looks like we moved from kramdown-rfc to a mix between [kramdown-rfc](https://github.com/cabo/kramdown-rfc)and [mmark](https://mmark.miek.nl/post/syntax) markdown. We need to use one or the other in order to have the workflows run properly.

I suggest moving to mmark syntax, as I was unable to get kramdown-rfc to fully work properly in some quick testing.

reviews.author: brownoxford
reviews.body: My comment was intended to be a request for changes. Explicitly adding now.
